articles.author: Yannick, Customer Care Team Leader - Pro Team
articles.description:
Improvement
  
Sounds impossible to find a guest message in seconds ? 
As we keep improving our features, we work closely with property users and managers like yourself to learn how we can help you run your business more efficiently. 
After several workshops, reflections, and feedback, our Smily team did several adjustments to help you use our centralized Inbox in order to simplify this daily communication.
We added several filters to help you find the conversations easily in the Inbox, you can now filter by the following criterias:
Conversation status
Assignee
Guest
Booking stage
Booking status
Rental
Booking tag
Rental tag

This way you can find the exact conversation you are looking for in a matter of seconds :) 
For more details please see the article from our manual
Wishing you all a pleasant day!
articles.title: Centralized inbox filters

articles.author: Audrey, Partnerships Development
articles.description:
Partners
  
We are today happy to announce our new partnership with a big French company : maeva !
We have been working closely to the maeva team to offer a new direct integration to our Smily clients. Therefore, you can easily push your properties to the maeva websites and promote your listings to millions of French guests using this channel !

About maeva.com
maeva.com is a tour operator specialized in vacation rentals which promotes properties in leisure and tourist areas.
Acquired by the Pierre et Vacances group in 2001, maeva.com is now appreciated by French travelers for its general vacation rental site presenting more than 50,000 properties and having hosted more than 200,000 travelers in the summer of 2022.
Their offer was initially including tourist residences mainly but they now …
articles.title: List your properties on maeva.com and get more bookings !

articles.description:
Description: An issue in the Tailscale coordination server allowed nodes with expired node keys to continue communicating with other nodes in a tailnet.
What happened?
There was a flaw in Tailscale’s logic for expiring node keys. If the set of nodes that can connect in a tailnet (the netmap) didn’t have any changes, then expired node keys were not immediately removed from the netmap. The longest delay in removal was 19 days, from 2022-12-20 to 2023-01-09.
Who is affected?
All tailnets with nodes whose node keys expired prior to 2023-01-12 may have been affected. Admins of a tailnet can view nodes with expired node keys in the admin console.
What is the impact?
Connections between nodes could continue after a node key expired, both when the expired node key was the source or when it was the destination of a connection. Connections to nodes with expired node keys would only be possible if they met all of the following criteria:
The peer node was in the same tailnet as, or shared into a tailnet with the node with the expired node key;
The peer node and the node with the expired node key were allowed to connect based on the access rules in the tailnet policy file at the time of expiry of the node key;
The tailnet’s netmap, including access rules, nodes added or removed from the tailnet, or connectivity of nodes in the tailnet did not change since the node key expiry; and
Tailscale had not deployed a change to the coordination server since the node key expiry.
What do I need to do?
No action is required. Tailscale has deployed a fix to the coordination server as of 2023-01-11.
Upgrade clients to v1.36 or later for an additional mitigation. In conjunction with the coordination server fix, this mitigation prevents nodes from connecting to nodes with expired node keys if the Tailscale coordination server is offline or unreachable.
Credits
We would like to thank Derek Ellis and Alex Eiser for reporting this issue.
articles.title: TS-2023-002

articles.description:
Description: An issue in the Tailscale coordination server allowed a malicious individual to share nodes from other tailnets to themselves, if they knew the node ID of the target.
What happened?
A bug in Tailscale’s node sharing logic allowed the creation of sharing invitations by unauthorized users. A malicious individual who knew a target node’s database ID could generate and accept a sharing invite for that node without being an admin of the target node’s tailnet.
This was possible for any node in any tailnet, as long as the individual knew the target’s node ID. The node ID is an integer used in the admin panel’s database, and is not related to the node “StableID” that is visible to Tailscale clients. A node’s ID is only visible in the API or admin console, by admins of either the node’s tailnet or a tailnet to which that node has already been shared. IDs are random 64-bit numbers that are not sequential or otherwise easily guessable.
The bug was introduced on 2022-09-14, reported to us on 2023-01-11, and remediated on 2023-01-12.
Who is affected?
All tailnets with nodes are affected.
What is the impact?
This vulnerability was not triggered or exploited. Analysis of tailnet logs shows that no unauthorized shares were created or accepted while the vulnerability was present, except as part of the proof of concept from the individual who reported the vulnerability.
Admins of a tailnet can review nodes that are shared out of their tailnet in the admin console. Sharing invites are logged as events in configuration audit logs. Admins can also review invites created and accepted in their configuration audit logs in the admin console.
What do I need to do?
No action is required. Tailscale has deployed a fix to the coordination server as of 2023-01-12, and verified that the vulnerability was not exploited.
Credits
We would like to thank Benjamin Roberts (tsujamin) for reporting this issue.
articles.title: TS-2023-001

Feb  9, 17:43 PST
Resolved - A fix has been implemented as of Feb 9, 10:00 UTC and webhooks should be returning names in full as expected.
We have been monitoring the situation since, and have marked the incident as resolved as of Feb 9, 20:10 UTC.
Do let us know via the Partner Portal if still experiencing issues.
We deeply regret this incident and sincerely apologize for any inconvenience caused to you.
Thank you for your patience and understanding.

Resolved - Engineering has implemented mitigations, which should have resolved performance issues. We’ll continue to monitor performance and provide updates if we run into issues again.
We found that page analytics events, such as page views and page edits, did not save during the time of this incident. Impacted users may see their page related analytics as undercounted for February 13, 2023. Our team is looking into how we can prevent this from happening in the future. We appreciate your patience while we work on making these improvements.

articles.description:
Issue summary:


On Tuesday February 14th, 2023 from 1:19 AM PST to 3:50 AM PST some customers reported an issue where the API method files.upload created a new message instead of uploading files in a thread.


Our team identified that the cause of the issue was linked to a recent update. This change was rolled back which fixed the issue. 


Note: This summary has been edited since its initial posting to better align with Slack's communication guidelines.
articles.title: Incident: Files upload API not uploading files to thread

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On Monday February 13th, 2023 at 07:00PM to Tuesday February 14th, 2023 at 01:02 AM PST, customers were unable to view threads in public channels they had not joined. This was caused by a recent code change - we've deployed a correction to this and the issue is now resolved.


Should customers continue to experience this behaviour, a hard refresh of the Slack client will fix this.
articles.title: Incident: Threads are currently not loading for some users

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On February 8, 2023, from 12:09 PM to 4:56 PM PST, customers on the Free, Pro, and Business+ plans may have experienced issues searching for messages in Slack.


We made a recent update that unintentionally prevented search results from populating correctly. We reverted the change, resolving the issue for all affected customers.
articles.title: Incident: Searches are failing for some users

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On February 2, 2023, from 3:00 PM PST to 6:00 PM PST, some customers may have received a Server Error when attempting to view the Slack App Developer page. 


We traced the failures back to a recent infrastructure change. When we rolled back the change, the problem was resolved for all affected customers.
articles.title: Incident: Some customers may be receiving a server error when viewing our Slack App Developer page

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

On January 31, 2023 from 11:40 AM PST to 11:55 AM PST, customers may have experienced issues with workflows not running as expected or posting duplicate messages. 


A network event prevented access to some of the database servers that support workflows. This disruption meant that the remaining servers were unable to handle the workflow load. 


We restarted the affected servers and manually increased the capacity to resolve the issue, restoring normal workflow behaviour.
articles.title: Incident: Errors running workflows

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

On January 31, 2023 from 9:44 AM to 3:17 PM PST, some customers may have experienced issues creating new workspaces. 


An error in our onboarding flow meant we were incorrectly assuming new workspaces had completed the onboarding process before any onboarding actually took place, leaving these newly created workspaces in an unusable limbo state. We reverted the change that caused the initial onboarding inconsistencies, then released a fix to resolve some dependencies from the reverted file. 


Everyone should be able to create new workspaces as normal once again, although you may experience some overzealous onboarding prompts as the system resolves any lingering inconsistencies.
articles.title: Incident: Users unable to enter team name when creating a workspace

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On January 25, 2023, from 2:41 PM PST to 6:17 PM PST, some customers may have experienced custom emojis failing to load.


We traced this back to a recent configuration change. When we rolled back the configuration, the problem was resolved for all affected customers.
articles.title: Notice: Some users having trouble with custom emoji.

articles.description:
Issue summary: On January 25, 2023 from 7:20 AM PDT to 7:46 AM PDT, some users experienced problems loading messages and threads, previewing files and sending messages in Slack. We traced this issue to a recent internal change and started reverting it immediately. Once this was reverted, the issue was resolved for all impacted users.


Note: We've edited the times in this summary to correct an error made in the initial version posted.
articles.title: Outage: Users having issues loading Slack

articles.description:
Issue summary:

From January 24, 2023 at 5:30 PM PST until January 24, 2023 at 10:20 PM PST, some customers who were using Slack in Japanese experienced a failure when using the "Send message to a thread" workflow step. 


We identified that this was caused by an earlier change we made to workflows and fixed the issue by reverting the earlier change.
articles.title: Incident: Workflows using 'Message thread' are failing for Japanese users.

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On January 24, 2023, from 5:50 AM to 9:30 AM PST, some customers experienced errors when opening threads and saw blank channels and direct message histories.


We traced this issue to an unexpected spike in a database load. We made a configuration change that restored full functionality to threads and conversations for all impacted users.


We are investigating ways to prevent this from occurring in the future.


You may need to reload Slack (Command/Ctrl + Shift + R) in order for the fix to be reflected on your end. We're sorry for the disruption we brought to your day.
articles.title: Incident: Threads, direct messages, and channels are currently not loading

articles.description:
Issue Summary:

From January 23, 2023 at 3:00 PM PST to January 24, 2023 at 7:02 AM PST some customers encountered an error when opening a workflow in a new window.


We determined this issue was caused by a recent change to how Slack handles additional windows. This change was reverted and the issue was corrected.
articles.title: Incident: Some customers may be encountering an error code when opening a workflow in a new window

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

On January 23, 2023 from 12:41 PM to 1:15 PM PST, some customers may have experienced issues executing workflows. 


A planned upgrade to part of our infrastructure caused an unexpected spike in database load. Our load-balancing system kicked in automatically, restoring normal workflow functionality.
articles.title: Incident: Some users may be experiencing issues with workflows

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On January 23, 2023 from around 12:41 PM to 1:15 PM PST, some customers may have experienced delays when opening channels and threads. 


We made a scheduled improvement to part of our infrastructure which inadvertently caused an increase in database load. Our automated recovery system intervened, balancing the load and resolving the issue for all affected customers.
articles.title: Incident: A small percentage of users may see a delayed response when loading channels and threads

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

From January 18th, 2023 7:45AM to 8:46PM PST some users experienced issues with missing channels and DMs in their sidebar. This affected only users of free teams.


This was due to a feature rollout which was rolled back and the issue is now resolved.
articles.title: Incident: Some customers may be missing channels and DMs in their sidebar

articles.description:
Issue summary:

From January 16th, 2023 04:59 to 08:38 AM PST, some users experienced issues creating Posts, using workflows, and trouble accessing Slack.  


We traced this back to an issue with our internal DNS configuration. Once this was identified and resolved, functionality was restored to all impacted users.
articles.title: Incident: Users may experience issues accessing or loading Slack, have trouble creating posts, and using Workflow Builder.

articles.description:
Issue summary:

From January 10th 04:11 AM PST to January 16th 07:54 PM PST, some of our fellow Slack colleagues were unable to access their workspaces on Android. We're happy to share that this issue was specifically related to our internal testing app, having no impact on the Slack production app nor our Customers.


This issue has been resolved and will have no impact on our future Android app releases.
articles.title: Incident: Some Android users may be experiencing issues when trying to access a workspace

Thank you for your understanding.

articles.description:
Jan 31, 07:00 CET
Completed - The scheduled maintenance has been completed.
Jan 31, 05:00 CET
In progress - Scheduled maintenance is currently in progress. We will provide updates as necessary.
Jan 26, 16:15 CET
Scheduled - Please note there is scheduled infrastructure maintenance on Tuesday 31st of January, between 5 AM and 7 AM CEST, when you can expect few short service interruptions. 
During this maintenance following services might be potentially affected:
- Migrations will not be available
- Shared hooks created within maintenance will not be accepted nor processed
- Logins to platform might be affected
- Registration of new subscribers won't be possible
- Invitations of new team members won't be possible
- E-mails and notifications might be delayed
- Password reset won't be possible
- Payments for subscription plans won't be accepted  
We will inform you once the maintenance is completed.
articles.title: Scheduled infrastructure maintenance
